title: How many total cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will The COVID Tracking Project report as of Sunday 17 May 2020?
preds: Count as of Friday 15 was 1,458,787. Data for Saturday is not available but we can use the data from Hopkins University which states 24,996  new case for Saturday. That leaves us with 1,500,000 - 1,458,787 - 24,996 = 16,217 new cases for Sunday to reach 1,500,000 cases. How likely are we to exceed 16,217 cases on  Sunday? Last Sunday we had 17'605 but we are on downward trend. The week before we had 24'892 on average except sunday. This week we are at 23'895. I guess it's 50/50.
16/05 23.5k on worldometer. They are averiging the same nr's. covidtracking is actually counting more since last sunday : Worldometer: +-114k, covidtracking:+-119k

Going back to my old forecast. I think there is just one more day of counting. If I'm wrong and Monday's numbers contribute to the total, at least this will keep me in line with the consensus. From earlier: "1,458,787 as of 5/16. Would need a little more than 41,000 cases to break 1,500,000, but we haven't seen more than 30,000 in a day for weeks. Leaving 1% just in case of the low probability of a massive influx of tests or something."
Easy Peasy. I wish stopping the pandemic were as straight forward.

I misunderstood the time stamps in my previous forecasts. Two more days of reporting left. Need an average of 21k per day in order to break 1,500,000. Slightly fewer cases tend to be reported on Sundays and Mondays. Still think it's more likely than not that we reach 1,500,000, especially since testing capacity has improved.
I'm reluctant to change my mind twice, but it's likely to be wise...

1,458,787 as of 5/16. Would need a little more than 41,000 cases to break 1,500,000, but we haven't seen more than 30,000 in a day for weeks. Leaving 1% just in case of the low probability of a massive influx of tests or something.

Fri May 15 2020	  56	  0	     1.433.696	    9.286.489	    10.720.185	2.457	81.729	10.720.185
Thu May 14 2020	  56	378.410	1.433.696	9.286.489 10.720.185	      2.457	  81.729	10.720.185 great great site. Perfect site. 
 I need to know what they had for yesterdays count. Do they have the same as other sites +27K....?
Then we have 1.46 on friday. So only 40k needed for 2 days....? How can you ever be accurate like this? Worldometers is now at 1.493. Fix this.

As the number of confirmed cases picks up in the Midwest and some South states recently, I am trying to find a pattern in the testing strategy (in case there is one...). It appears to me that the increase in total new tests of the recent days have been assigned to half a dozen states which have not been tested very intensely (under-tested) before, as the Northeast states and D.C. plus CA have stood in the focus and absorbed most of the tests available. For the last four days it's been more confirmed cases, while the positivity rate has remained by and large unchanged. Maybe there is some kind of a correlation between the number or date of tests assigned to an individual state or county and its distance to D.C. ...Anyway those latest additional test may also have a larger range in testing time lag (average inherent time lag between the test being taken has been recorded and a negative or positive result has been recorded under the COVID Tracking project.), maybe even 12 to 96 hours, differing from state to state and maybe depending on its geographical "remoteness".
All together this makes it harder to predict any effect of an increase in new tests today on the absolute numbers of increases in confirmed cases in the days ahead.
I was too optimistic once again. It'll be close around 1,500,000 positive cases.
1,433,696 as of 5/15. Almost no chance there will be less than 1,450,000. Very slight chance there will be more than 1,500,000.
Based on the positive numbers from the last few days.

1,407,507 as of May 14. Three days to go. 20,000-25,000 additional cases per day. Accounting for some degree of error, it's very likely that we'll be somewhere between 1,460,000 and 1,490,000 at the end of the day on May 17.
Wed 13 may (1,407,507) + moving average of 20k a day, with 4 more days to go > 1,450,000 and <1.5m No significant changes to confirmation rate expected due to incubation time
Currently at 1.407 million, with about 20-25k added per day. Unless there is a large change in daily totals, it looks pretty solid for the 3rd bucket.
Increasing over daily average of 20k new cases per day
My tracking is similar to @dglid, I am getting 1,469,452 trending from May 9th as the linear tracking I used previously appears to be sloping downwards.

Nevermind, error was in importing data from CTP site. Fixed; back to all in on bin 3. Current May 17th forecast: 1,481,647
Previous May 17th forecasts: 1,493,483 | 1,485,423 | 1,482,289 | 1,480,266

Updating linear day-of-week-adjusted model [1] with latest data. Also looks like I had a data error that caused some issues. Current May 17th forecast: 1,499,865
Previous May 17th forecasts: 1,493,483 | 1,485,423 | 1,482,289 | 1,480,266 [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1858575626

Obviously, The COVID Tracking Project cannot afford to publish in time as announced (4 pm EDT), but always stands by for NY (which means roughly 2.5k cases more instead of less). I wonder if you can call that a reliable source that way, maybe the project should refrain from stating a specific publish time instead. Illinois seems to get out of control, Virginia is worse, too, and the Wisconsin verdict bodes pretty ill. Too much bad news for a good scenario. I changed my mind. Sad to see how ineffective stay-at-home orders have proved in the US compared to Europe's response when it comes to slowing the growth. What a poor judgment of the administration doing a "good job".
Things are not slowing. With more testing and fewer states with stay at home orders, cases will certainly accelerate, but most of the acceleration of cases will be realized after May 17.

Updating linear day-of-week-adjusted model [1] with latest data. Current May 17th forecast: 1,480,266
Previous May 17th forecasts: 1,493,483 | 1,485,423 | 1,482,289 [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1858575626
Appears to be stable at this stage.

Ok, it seems like there's much going wrong today in a few places important for the outbreak such as CA, GA, IL, MD, MA, OH, TX,... and growth seems to accelerate there from an already large base. And even NY has probably added some 800 extra cases today. Maybe I underestimated the testing time lag and it is rather 24 to 48 hours. It is probably going to be a tough call anyway and buffers are melting. It's risky, but I am betting on a tame Sunday this week. Unfortunately, now I see that my last estimate was mistyped by one level. One should not do superforecasting before doing off late in the night/early morning ... What I predicted 40% (1,5-1,55) was meant for (1,45-1,50), etc. Anyway, now I increase my confidence as the weeks closes and the U.S. in general does not take efficient measures lately.
Based on the current level and the trends to date
currently 1,370,000 as of 13th May. Increasing by (averaged) approx 24K/day so may expect to see further 125K by sunday ie around 1,475,000 cases.

Newly confirmed cases 17 May 2020: approximately 11,500 It may seem weird, but I forecast under the assumption that the big game (e.g. superspreaders, patients with obvious symptoms) have been reeled in, thus the positivity rate in testing should decline, which is, by and large, reflected by reality. As a result it is now getting ever harder to detect (and test and most importantly confirm and isolate) new cases, since many infections out in the society now will be asymptomatic. The numbers of daily increases in confirmed cases may have seen a breach of trend within the last week from a volatile stagnation into a modest decline.
It depends on the details in testing method and the assumed average inherent time lag (I assume 12 to 24 hours) between the test being taken has been recorded and a negative or positive result has been recorded under the COVID Tracking project.
If that holds, then it is interesting to see that a roughly constant level of new tests at about 300,000 tests per day after 7 May 2020 produced new confirmed cases on the following day at an absolute increase that's been declining between 9.4 per cent to 18.9 per cent day over day. An increase of new tests on Monday 11 May 2020 of 41,9 percent to 388,296 produced a scant increase in newly confirmed cases of 15.3 percent on Tuesday 12 May 2020, with some uncertainty due to the cut in the day count. As the number of test returned to its previous level on Tuesday 12 May 2020 (289,472), one could expect a sharp drop in newly confirmed cases today 13 May 2020 by up to 30 per cent.
So today's numbers will determine which path the numbers are actually on, and which one of the two most recent daily increases is the outlier. Until then, I leave my projection steady.
After this week, however, most of the infected individuals in the society will be imho asymptomatic or pre-symptomatic, which in turn are those with a higher individual reproduction rate; already in the week after Monday 18 2020 the average numbers of daily increases maybe return a next plateau of about 22,000 on average. It would be illusive and premature to expect the modest decline in the rate of newly confirmed cases to continue forever...
On the bubble, straddle the brink at least for today.
If the next 5 days are just linear.

Estimating about 20,000 cases a day on the low end and 25,000 on the high end based on latest trends. That puts it pretty solidly in the 450 to 500 range, but with New York cases steadily declining there's a chance it drops down into the lower category.
About 25k per day, with 1.34 million as a base, giving about 1.49 million as an estimate to start.
The rate of about 25,000 per day would lead to about 1,495,000 cases by next Sunday.

Less than 200,000 new cases again this week?

Played around for a few minutes with linear forecast based on last ten days' data. Skewing higher due to continued increased availability of testing, and likelihood of increased cases due to ongoing relaxation of social distancing measures in many states.

If testing increase it should result in more. More opening up can result in some more cases but may be a lag before they show-up. 2% growth rate as seen in this chart. https://coronavirus.1point3acres.com/
Initial forecast to be checked daily.

I'm enjoying trying to get better at forecasting this!  (Only wish my Brier score was "enjoying" it, too!)  I crunched some #  using rolling 7 day averages:  add, subtract, multiply, divide  (simple math for a simple mind!)
Then, I "massaged" my numbers for an increase in tests done. It's very interesting to me that as the # of tests has increased the % of positive cases has fallen.  For example, on April 13th when 129,114 tests were done, 19.3% were positive, whereas for the last week the average has been 8.8%, when 276,308 tests were done on the average day.  This is how/why even though the # of new tests has increased to almost double, the # of new positives has not increased much. From what I've read and been told, almost nobody used to get tested until they were sicker than a dog, at the ER, and in a high risk category, now asymptomatic people are getting tested at job sites; this explains the lower % of positive cases, I think.

Based on the current number of infected people, the current weekly moving average growth rate of infections paired with the assumption of its decline by 1% per day, I end up with a figure of 1,442,000 million people on May 17. As this figure is fairly close to 1,450,000, I assign a 20% probability that the figure might actually be less than 1,500,000.
Linearly tracking since early April indicates: 1,538,364

Seems to be slowing down a bit. Need to have >25k on average for 7 reporting days to be > 1,5. Last week was 170K. Have to follow up to see where it's heading. Think an increase in cases is more likely for next week.
